Name: Afghanistan
Authentication Method Details: Biometric + PIN/Machine-readable chip
Use Cases Details: Welfare, Financial,Immigration, Private Sector
Data Collected: Name, DOB, address, gender, nationality, ethnicity, religion, biometrics (fingerprints, iris), photo, family lineage
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: 53 percent women without IDs, low literacy rate, high fee ($10)
Known Controversies Details: The lack of distribution centers in many underdeveloped provinces forces numerous citizens to undertake long and costly journeys to major cities, such as Kabul, to obtain their identification documents.
Overview: Afghanistan’s e‑Tazkira is a launched and operational foundational digital identity system, managed by the NSIA under Taliban rule. It is a smart-card based polycarbonate ID with embedded biometric data including fingerprints and iris scans, alongside detailed socio-demographic information. Official rollout began in 2018, and by early 2025, over 14–15 million cards have been issued, including to diaspora through Asan Khedmat centers. While designed for comprehensive integration across banking, SIM registration, voting (when applicable), and public services, it faces major inclusion challenges, especially among women and rural populations. Moreover, the system has been flagged for surveillance risks, corruption in distribution, and concerns over the Taliban’s control of sensitive biometric databases. The legal underpinning comes from the 2013 Population Registration Act and subsequent e‑Tazkira rollout policies.
Key Developments:
2010s – NATO/AABIS biometric systems piloted for populations and security forces
2013 – Population Registration Act enacted, enabling future digital ID systems 
2018 – Launch of e‑Tazkira; President Ghani first recipient 
2021 – Taliban seizes control of biometric database, raising data misuse concerns 
2025 – Over 14–15M cards issued; distribution centers expanded; mobile teams deployed; diaspora included via Asan Khedmat 
Ongoing – Reports of corruption, bribery, access delays, and data-driven surveillance continue

Name: Albania
Authentication Method Details: Fingerprint, facial image
ID Medium Details: Smart Card + Web Portal (e-Albania) + future mobile/digital ID
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healthcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Private sector (eALEAT)
Interoperatability Details: National Integrated + travel within Europe (Schengen)
Data Collected: Name, DOB, personal ID number, fingerprint, face, address, nationality, etc.
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: mandatory, national coverage, though digital services access varies regionally
Overview: Since 2009, Albania has issued a biometric national ID card (Letërnjoftim) and biometric passports under a PPP concession led by IDEMIA/ALEAT. The system is mandatory, embedded in EU visa-liberalization processes. Citizens authenticate via fingerprints and facial recognition through their smart cards, mobile OTPs, or PINs. Albania's unified e-government portal, e‑Albania, is administered by AKSHI and leverages these IDs for public services like health, welfare, taxation, and private-sector access (e-signing, SIMs). Biometric IDs are required for voting; about 120,000 non-compliant citizens faced exclusion in the 2025 elections. While adoption is widespread and data protection aligns with EU norms, the system faced minor disruptions from cyberattacks. Technology partners include IDEMIA, Smartmatic, and OSCE across sectors.
Overview Spotlight: Since 2009, Albania has issued a biometric national ID card (Letërnjoftim) and biometric passports under a PPP concession led by IDEMIA/ALEAT.
Key Developments:
2003 – National personal identity number structure defined by ministerial decree 
2007 – Central population database created; biometric ID tender launched with Sagem 
2009 – Rollout of biometric ID cards begins; 1.4M issued in first half
2013 – Concession extended to 2023; integration with EU Schengen visa facilitation 
2009–Present – ALEAT provides eID services for e-government, e-signature, and digital authentication 
2021 – Smartmatic’s biometric voting system used in local and parliamentary elections (5,500+ devices) 
2025 – ~120k voters excluded for lacking biometric IDs; potential diaspora inclusion adjustments underway
Key Developments Spotlight:
2003 – National personal identity number structure defined by ministerial decree
2007 – Central population database created; biometric ID tender launched with Sagem 
2009 – Rollout of biometric ID cards begins; 1.4M issued in first half
2013 – Concession extended to 2023; integration with EU Schengen visa facilitation 
2009–Present – ALEAT provides eID services for e-government, e-signature, and digital authentication 
2021 – Smartmatic’s biometric voting system used in local and parliamentary elections (5,500+ devices) 
2025 – ~120k voters excluded for lacking biometric IDs; potential diaspora inclusion adjustments underway

Name: Algeria
Authentication Method Details: Biometric (fingerprint match-on-card) + PIN + contact/contactless chip
ID Medium Details: Smart card (dual-chip polycarbonate) and an ePassport by Gemalto
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healthcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Immigration, Private sector
Interoperatability Details: National integrated; ICAO-compliant chips for border/passport
Data Collected: Photo, name, DOB, place of birth, signature, gender, blood type, fingerprints, national ID number, address
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: nationwide, free issuance; some rural/elderly digital access challenges
Funding Source Details: Domestic public funding (via MoI); part of Digital Algeria 2030 strategy
Legal Framework:
Law 10‑04 (NIN, 2010)
e-signature law 15‑05 (2015)
Biometric ID deployment policy
Managing Authority: Ministry of Interior (Direction des titres sécurisés)
Third-Party Access: Government agencies, e-gov portals, banks, telecoms
Overview: Algeria launched its biometric national ID card (CNIBE) in early 2016, under the Ministry of Interior's secure documents directorate. The polycarbonate smart card includes dual chips—one contactless ICAO chip for travel and biometric fingerprint match-on-card to ensure robust identity assurance. Issued free of charge to all adults, over 16 million cards had been distributed by 2019. The ID is mandatory for elections, KYC, e-government access, welfare, education, and serves as a passport/travel document. The system aligns with ICAO standards and integrates within national public services, though public privacy frameworks continue evolving. The project, supported by Thales/Gemalto under the Digital Algeria 2030 strategy, features modern e-signature and security measures
Key Developments:
2010 – Law established national ID number infrastructure
2012 – First biometric e-passports launched; groundwork for CNIBE 
2015 – E-signature legal framework introduced (Law 15‑05) 
2016 – Biometric ID card rollout begins nationwide 
2019 – Reached 16 million card issuance 
2021 – Ongoing e-government expansion; digital services integration; PKI review due to 1024‑bit RSA concerns

Name: American Samoa
ID Medium Details: Physical Card
Interoperatability Details: Domestic Travel
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: REAL ID adoption rate is 16 percent
Overview: American Samoa enforces REAL ID-compliant driver's licenses as its primary form of official identity within the territory. Beginning May 7, 2025, residents must hold a REAL ID for domestic U.S. air travel and federal facility access . These physical licenses include secure marking and data but no biometric components. They are used widely across banks, healthcare, education, and private sector services, aligning with strong federal privacy and data protection standards. Despite broad access, residents have faced processing backlogs at DMV offices, leading to long waits . The system operates in a siloed manner specific to U.S. jurisdictions with no broader digital ID infrastructure.
Key Developments:
2005 – REAL ID Act enacted federally.

May 7, 2025 – American Samoa begins enforcing REAL ID driver’s licenses for travel and federal access

Name: Andorra
Use Cases Details: Financial, Healthcare, Education
Overview: Andorra has initiated a foundational digital identity portfolio, a hybrid mobile/web-based digital wallet piloted from 2024, managed by OSCEPA and Andorra Digital. It enables citizens to store verifiable credentials—like ID cards, permits, and diplomas—and share them securely with public and private entities under user-controlled consent. Designed in alignment with eIDAS 2, it supports cross-border interoperability, particularly within the EU. Authentication relies on digital certificates and mobile PINs, with no biometric component. Early researches target use cases in banking, social services, taxation, healthcare, education, and identity verification. The system is supported by strong EU-style data protection frameworks, developed with Var Group. Public rollout continues with gradual scaling.
Key Developments:
2023–2024 – Development of digital wallet system, infrastructure design, and legal groundwork 
October 2024 – Official "Digital Identity Citizen Portfolio" unveiled to the public and institutions via Biometric Update coverage 
2025 (ongoing) – Development phases underway across public administration, finance, health, education, aligned with eIDAS 2

Name: Angola
System Name: Bilhete de identidade de cidadão nacional (BI)
Authentication Method Details: Biometric (fingerprints) + visual security + PIN optional
ID Medium Details: Smart Card / LaserCard optical-polymer card with secure chip
Use Cases Details: Voting, Financial, Immigration, Private sector (KYC)
Data Collected: Full name, DOB, address, photo, ten fingerprints, signature, National Number
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Rural/mobile rollout using trucks, mobile teams. ~12M without ID in 2021
Funding Source Details: Domestic budget and India-funded DPI credit
Legal Framework: National Civil Registration Law. Biometric ID law
Overview: Angola has implemented a biometric national ID (Bilhete de Identidade) managed by the Ministry of Justice, rolling out modern smart-card and LaserCard optical credentials since around 2009–2010. The card stores up to ten fingerprints and a photo, supporting both offline and online verification via chip or secure printing. With around 6.5 million cards issued by 2017, the country is continuing enrollment via fixed centers and mobile units to reach its full adult population. The ID is mandatory, linked to voter registration, KYC for banking and SIMs, and early stages of integration into digital public infrastructure supported by a $200M Indian credit line. While it brings authentication convenience, approximately 12 million Angolans remain unregistered, and efforts continue across rural areas. Angola’s program is backed by HID Global, India, and private-sector verifiers like Dojah.
Key Developments:
2009 – ID replacement initiative launched; cards designed with biometric & optical features; HID Global contracted 
2009 – National rollout begins; initial issuance via 27 fixed centers and mobile units 
By 2017 – ~6.5M smart cards issued across 243 issuance centers 
2023–2025 – Angola secures $200M credit line from India to support DPI, digital ID, e-payments, and social registries 
2025 – DPI-driven expansion underway; integration with public services and KYC processes; private verifiers onboarded

Name: Antigua and Barbuda
Managing Authority: Ministry of Information, Broadcasting, Telecommunications and Information Technology (MIBTIT)

Name: Argentina
Authentication Method Details: Biometric (fingerprint, facial), PIN/QR, digital signature, mobile-based (Mi Argentina app)
ID Medium Details: Smart Card (DNI), Digital Mobile ID (DNI Digital in Mi Argentina app), Paper (legacy), e-passport
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healthcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Immigration (e-passport), Private sector
Interoperatability Details: Nationally integrated; interoperability with Mercosur for travel with DNI card; digital ID accepted for various online services
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, unique DNI number, fingerprint, face, address, gender, nationality, digital signature, CUIL (Tax Identification Number)
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Near-universal coverage (>98% of citizens have DNI); some gaps in remote/rural and elderly populations
Known Controversies Details: Minor issues with data access and delays; historic concerns with biometric data security; criticism of privacy safeguards by NGOs
Funding Source Details: Government budget, international technical assistance (e.g., Inter-American Development Bank for Mi Argentina app)
Legal Framework: National Identity Law, Electronic Signature Law, Data Protection Law, RENAPER regulations
Third-Party Access: Government agencies, financial institutions, some private sector via regulated APIs (Mi Argentina)
Overview: Argentina has achieved near-universal digital identity coverage through its Documento Nacional de Identidad (DNI), a biometric smart card mandatory for all citizens and residents. Since 2017, the DNI Digital—an official digital credential available in the “Mi Argentina” mobile app—has enabled secure access to e-government, health, and financial services. Authentication uses fingerprints, facial biometrics, and digital signatures, and the system underpins public services from voting and health care to digital banking and education. RENAPER, under the Ministry of the Interior, manages both issuance and interoperability, while the Data Protection Law (25.326) governs personal data use. Argentina’s digital identity framework is one of Latin America's most advanced, but privacy and rural inclusion remain points of public and NGO attention.
Key Developments:
1968 – DNI (physical, paper) becomes mandatory under Law
2009 – Launch of biometric DNI smart card; national rollout begins
2012 – Biometric e-passport introduced for citizens
2017 – Launch of DNI Digital in the Mi Argentina app
2020 – COVID-19 certificate and vaccination records added to digital ID system
2021–2025 – Expansion of digital government and interoperability; pilot of facial authentication and e-signature in mobile app

Name: Armenia
Authentication Method Details: eID with an ID card and reader and mobile ID (mID) with a uSIM
ID Medium Details: Smart-card ID, biometric e-passport, mobile PKI (SIM/e-signature)
Use Cases Details: Voting, Financial, Tax, immigration
Interoperatability Details: National integration; e-signature works with EEU & some EU infra. Working on joint ID program with Georgia and Moldova
Data Collected: Name, DOB, gender, ID #, photo, fingerprint (optional), address, nationality, digital signature, marital status
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Rural/elderly digital-uptake gaps
Known Controversies Details: Privacy-enforcement critiques; digital-literacy gaps; biometric opt-in debates
Funding Source Details: State budget; support from EU4Digital, World Bank, UNDP
Managing Authority: Law on Identity Documents; Law on Personal Data; Law on E-Docs & E-Signature
Third-Party Access: Regulated access for gov’t agencies, banks, telecoms; expanding private e-signature use
Overview: Armenia rolled out biometric passports & national e-ID cards in 2012, making modern IDs mandatory at 16+. The e-ID enables PKI digital signatures, and the e-government portal now supports health, social-service, and tax transactions. Uptake is strong, though rural and elderly groups face digital-literacy barriers. The 2015 personal-data law provides a moderate privacy framework; alignment with EU standards is ongoing. Support from the EU, World Bank, and UNDP has driven further e-gov upgrades, while interoperability projects link Armenia’s e-signature to EEU and some EU systems.
Key Developments:
2004 – Electronic Document & E-Signature Law adopted
2012 – Biometric passport & e-ID card launched
2015 – Personal-Data Law passed; mobile-signature pilot
2018-23 – e-Gov upgrades & EU/EEU interoperability projects
2025 – privacy-law reforms underway, EU4Digital cross-border digital ID interoperability pilot successful

Name: Australia
Authentication Method Details: myGovID enrolment combines a facial-recognition check (Biometric) with a device-bound public-key pair (Cryptography)
ID Medium Details: Users primarily authenticate via the myGovID Mobile App, but can also access credentials through the myGov Web Portal—hence a hybrid delivery
Use Cases Details: Healthcare, Social, Financial, Tax
Interoperatability Details: Federated – Commonwealth, some state/territory services; Trust framework allows accredited private providers
Data Collected: Name, DoB, email, Aussie address, document numbers, facial biometric template, mobile-device public key
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Smartphone or photo-ID prerequisites disadvantage some rural, elderly & Indigenous users
Known Controversies Details: Privacy laws were only recently introduced in 2024. Ongoing civil-society scrutiny
Third-Party Access: Only accredited entities under Digital ID Act; strict consent & privacy safeguards; OAIC oversees privacy compliance
Overview: Since 2019 the myGovID (now myID) credential has allowed Australians to access more than 130 federal services online. The scheme is voluntary, smartphone-based and uses a one-time selfie check against government-issued documents. In May 2024 Parliament passed the Digital ID Act 2024, creating a statutory regime that opens Australia’s federated Digital ID network to state governments and the private sector, with the ACCC as economic regulator and the OAIC enforcing privacy. Adoption now exceeds 10 million users, but policy debates continue over inclusion for those without compatible devices and over safeguards once banks and big tech firms join the ecosystem
Key Developments:
2015 – Trusted Digital Identity Framework drafted; pilot digital-identity log-ins begin
2019 – Public launch of myGovID app for ATO and business services
2021 – myGovID surpasses 5 million users; Medicare and Services Australia integrate the credential
2023 – Digital ID Bill introduced to Parliament after nationwide privacy and accreditation consultation
2024 – Digital ID Act enacted; ACCC named regulator; private-sector accreditation window opens

Name: Austria
Authentication Method Details: facial-biometric liveness check (Biometric) plus device-bound public-key pair (Cryptography)
ID Medium Details: Mobile App (ID Austria / Digitales Amt) + optional smart-card (Bürgerkarte) & secure Web Portal
Use Cases Details: Healthcare, Social, Financial, Tax, Immigration
Interoperatability Details: Conforms to EU eIDAS; cross-border login for EU digital services (eIDAS node)
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, address, Austrian personal ID number, document details, facial biometric template, device key
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Disadvantage for some elderly & rural residents
Known Controversies Details: Usability complaints during migration from Handy-Signatur; privacy NGOs call for clearer biometric-data deletion rules
Funding Source Details: Federal budget, EU CEF/eIDAS programme grants
Internation Partners: European Commission (eIDAS), EU4Digital, Digital Nations forum
Legal Framework: e-Government Act (2004), Signature & Trust-Services Act (2019), Data Protection Act (DSG 2018)
Third-Party Access: Only accredited public bodies & private providers under eIDAS and Austria’s e-Gov Act; user consent required
Overview: ID Austria is the country’s single sign-on digital identity, replacing the earlier Handy-Signatur. Citizens enrol via a one-time facial-biometric check that binds a device-resident private key. The credential is accepted across more than 250 federal, state and municipal services, plus qualified e-signature for banks, telecoms and notaries. By mid-2025 about 4 million Austrians use ID Austria regularly. The system is governed by the e-Government Act, Austria’s strong GDPR-aligned Data Protection Act, and EU eIDAS rules. Ongoing work focuses on full population coverage and integration into the forthcoming EU Digital Identity Wallet.
Key Developments:
2004 – e-Government Act and Citizen-Card framework adopted
2009 – Handy-Signatur mobile-signature service launched nationally
2012 – Biometric e-passports integrated with eID services
2022 – National roll-out of ID Austria begins, replacing Handy-Signatur
2023 – Migration completed; private-sector onboarding framework published
2025 – 4 M+ users; pilot tests for EU Digital Identity Wallet interoperability successful

Name: Azerbaijan
Authentication Method Details: PIN (Password/PIN) + chip-based Cryptography (qualified e-signature); biometric fingerprint check possible during on-site verification
ID Medium Details: Smart Card (ID) + Mobile SIM (ID on phone) + e-government Web Portal (myGov.az)
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healtcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, private sector (telecom SIM registration, e-commerce)
Interoperatability Details: National e-government integration
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, gender, personal-ID number, address, photo, fingerprints, digital-signature certificates
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Mobile-ID uptake lags in some rural & elderly groups
Known Controversies Details: Civil-society calls for stronger privacy oversight; 2018 roll-out delays due to chip supply; limited transparency on biometric-data retention
Managing Authority: State Agency for Public Service & Social Innovations
Third-Party Access: Government bodies, banks, telecoms under consent-based, certificate-authority rules
Overview: Azerbaijan’s identity ecosystem combines a biometric smart-card ID—mandatory for every citizen over 16—and ASAN İmza, a SIM-based mobile ID that delivers qualified electronic signatures. Since nationwide issuance began in 2018, more than eight million next-generation ID cards have replaced older paper documents, each embedding a chip with fingerprints, photo and e-signature certificates. Citizens and businesses use these credentials across more than 600 e-government and commercial services on myGov.az, including tax filing, banking, health care and social-benefit portals. The Ministry of Internal Affairs issues the cards, while ASAN Service manages mobile-ID enrolment under the Electronic Signature Law. Data-privacy rules stem from the 2010 Personal Data Law, rated moderate due to limited supervisory capacity.
Key Developments:
2013 – ASAN İmza mobile-ID service launched nationwide
2018 – Biometric electronic ID cards issued; first card presented to President Ilham Aliyev
2020 – myGov.az portal integrates ID card and ASAN İmza for one-stop e-services
2023 – Legal amendments enable remote e-ID onboarding; new ID cards include built-in e-signature certs
2025 – > 8 M biometric IDs & 3 M mobile IDs issued

Name: Bahrain
Authentication Method Details: Chip-based PKI (Cryptography) + PIN (Password/PIN) for the card; eKey 2.0 adds selfie liveness (Biometric)
ID Medium Details: Smart Card + Mobile App (eKey 2.0) + Web Portal (Bahrain.bh/myGov)
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healtcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Immigration, private sector (Growing – telcos, utilities, e-commerce adopting eKey 2.0 SSO)
Interoperatability Details: Fully integrated with national e-government; pilots under way with GCC digital-ID working group
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, national ID number, address, nationality, blood type, photo, fingerprints, digital-certificate data
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: smartphone/biometric onboarding still a barrier for some elderly & migrant workers
Known Controversies Details: 2018 chip-supply delay; civil-society calls for greater transparency on biometric retention; PDPL enforcement still maturing
Legal Framework: Electronic Transactions Law 2006, PDPL 2018 (+ 2022 executive regulations), Civil ID Law
Third-Party Access: Government bodies, licensed banks & telcos via certificate authority and PDPL consent rules
Overview: Bahrain issues a biometric smart-card identity to every citizen and resident and operates eKey 2.0, a mobile, selfie-based single-sign-on credential. The card’s chip stores fingerprints, facial image and PKI certificates, enabling secure PIN-based verification at government kiosks and banks. eKey 2.0, launched in 2025, adds password-less facial authentication on smartphones and is already being integrated by telcos and utilities for friction-free onboarding. The system is run by the Information & eGovernment Authority (iGA) and governed by the 2018 Personal Data Protection Law. While uptake exceeds 95 % for the physical card, digital-ID usage continues to grow as more private-sector services adopt eKey 2.0.
Key Developments:
2007 – Smart-card national ID rolled out to citizens and residents by Thales
2011 – eKey single-sign-on platform launched for e-government services
2018 – Biometric smart-cards upgraded; fingerprint & PKI certificates embedded
2023 – Personal Data Protection Law fully in force with executive regulations
2025 – eKey 2.0 launches with biometric by provided by Beyon Connect

Name: Bangladesh
Authentication Method Details: Chip-based PKI (Cryptography) + PIN (Password/PIN) on the card; NID Wallet adds SMS/OTP and selfie check
ID Medium Details: Smart Card + Mobile App (NID Wallet) + Web Portal (services.nidw.gov.bd)
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healthcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Immigration
Interoperatability Details: National e-gov integration
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, 17-digit NID number, address, photo, all fingerprints, facial template, parental data
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Birth-registration gaps & smartphone access issues for rural women and older citizens
Known Controversies Details: 2023–25 data leaks (50 M+ records exposed); EC suspended services for institutions linked to breaches
Internation Partners:
EC
DFID
Netherland
UNDP
Norway
Sweden
Switzerland
Denmark
Korea
Legal Framework: National Identity Registration Act 2013; Electronic Signature & ICT Act 2006; draft PDPA 2024
Third-Party Access: Government agencies, banks & telcos via licensed NID verification service
Overview: Bangladesh issues a biometric Smart NID card to every citizen aged 18 +, embedding ten fingerprints and a facial template alongside PKI certificates. The card is legally mandatory and underpins over 600 public and private digital services, from voter enrolment and social-welfare payouts to e-KYC in banking. Since 2022 the NID Wallet app has enabled mobile presentation of the credential with selfie/OTP verification, reaching more than ten million installations. Governance lies with the Election Commission’s National Identity Registration Wing, though a 2023 law transfering ultimate oversight to the Home Ministry. It is still managed by the Election Commission. Privacy remains a concern: multiple high-profile leaks between 2023–25 exposed tens of millions of records, and Bangladesh’s draft Personal Data Protection Act 2024 is still awaiting parliamentary passage. Despite those challenges, Smart NID coverage exceeds 95 % of adults and is integral to Dhaka’s “Smart Bangladesh 2027” digital-transformation agenda.
Key Developments:
2006 – Paper laminated NID introduced nationwide
2013 – ASAN Imza-style e-KYC pilots begin for banking sector
2016 – Biometric Smart NID card rolled out country-wide
2022 – NID Wallet mobile ID released to the public
2023 – Major NID database leak reported; EC launches audit of connected institutions
2025 – Draft Personal Data Protection Act tabled in parliament; Smart NID coverage passes 55 million smart card

Name: Barbados
Authentication Method Details: On-card PKI (Cryptography) + PIN (Password/PIN) + fingerprint or face match (Biometric) for high-assurance services
ID Medium Details: Contact-less Smart Card + Trident eID Mobile App + Web Portal (gov.bb)
Use Cases Details: Voting, Healthcare, Welfare, Financial, Tax, Immigration, Private sector (telcos, utilities, real-estate conveyancing adopt qualified e-signature)
Interoperatability Details: Designed for CARICOM Single ICT Space
Data Collected: Name, date of birth, 12-digit national ID number, address, nationality, fingerprints, facial template, digital-certificate data
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: 90 % of adult population converted by 2024; rural elders & non-smartphone users targeted via assisted-registration drives
Known Controversies Details: 2022 rollout delays due to chip shortages; civil-society requests clearer opt-out rules for biometric retention
Legal Framework: Electoral & Identification Card Act (rev. 2022), Electronic Transactions Act 2001, Data Protection Act 2019
Managing Authority: Ministry of Industry, Innovation, Science and Technology (MIST)
Third-Party Access: Accredited public bodies & licensed private-sector relying parties under Data Protection Act; user consent via Trident eID app
Overview: Barbados replaced its legacy laminated voter card with the Trident ID, a contact-less polycarbonate e-ID containing a secure element, fingerprints and a facial image. Paired with the Trident eID mobile wallet, the credential supports qualified electronic signatures and single-sign-on to more than 120 government and commercial services. Managed by the Ministry of Innovation and the Electoral & Boundaries Commission, the scheme is anchored in the GDPR-style Data Protection Act 2019. By 2024, about 90 % of adults had been issued, and mobile adoption continues to rise as banks, telcos and the planned central-bank digital-currency pilot integrate the credential.
Key Developments:
2019 – Data Protection Act receives Royal Assent
2021 – Digital ID & e-Payments project launched; Trident ID pilot begins
2022 – First contact-less biometric e-ID cards produced; chip-shortage delays resolved
2023 – Nationwide mass issuance of Trident ID; Trident eID mobile wallet released on iOS & Android
2024 – 90 % adult coverage achieved; CARICOM interoperability proof-of-concept completed

Name: Fiji
Use Cases Details: Essential service, including healthcare, social welfare, finance, and education
Managing Authority: Reserve Bank of Fiji and the National ID Steering Committee
Overview: The National ID project in Fiji was first established in 2024 to help Fijians get access to essential services, and the vision was further expanded on in 2025.
Key Developments:
2024 - Fiji announced a Digital ID project to help Fijians get access to essential services
2025 - Laid foundation over vision, strategy, and future for a Fijian National ID system and cabinet gives approval to implement it

Name: Finland
Managing Authority: Ministry of Finance and the Digital and Population Data Services Agency
Overview Spotlight:
2024 - Finland announced that they were going to pursue a national digital ID project with plans to be complete by 2026
2025 - Finland and Bahrain partner on Digital ID project

Name: France
Authentication Method Details: It is an app that is available of Android and IOS
ID Medium Details: Mobile_App
Use Cases Details: This ID can be used to prove identity digitally. It can also be used to access government services.
Interoperatability Details: Requires a national ID as proof of ID to set up
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: The digital ID system is currently being expanded to all residency card holders
Known Controversies Details: France has a digital ID; however, they have been opposed to the EU's digital ID initiatives, citing data privacy and security concerns.
Managing Authority: National Agency for Secure Documents, Agence Nationale des Titres Sécurisés (ANTS)
Overview Spotlight:
2022 - First plot program 
2024 - Accessible to anyone that wishes to have France Identité. Have to have a new French identity card, be of legal age, and have at least an Android 11 or iOS 16.6

Overview Spotlight: 2025 - Georgia has expressed interest and a plan to build digital ID system

ID Medium Details: Mobile_App

Name: Mozambique
Authentication Method Details: Uses botht the Unique Citizens Identification Number and Biometric Data
ID Medium Details: NUIC is linked to smart card and passport used for entry into the country, voting registration, educational uses, financial operations and drivers liceneses
Use Cases Details: A prerequisite in obtaining a digital ID is a Unique Citizen Identification number (NUIC) obtained through a birth certificate. The number is connected to the digital ID cards, passports and health cards.
Interoperatability Details:
thogh initiaitves 
have been 
mentioned to 
carry out a 
regionally recognized 
digital ID among 
Southern African 
Development Community (SADC),
 progress has been 
slow to recognize 
digital ID's among 
neighboring 
countries in formal ways.
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: connectivity issues in rural sectors of Mozambique, Utility gap as diverse groups of Mozambique citizens (women, disabled) dont have the digital literacy skills to increase the demand of digital ID's.
Known Controversies Details: In the 2024 Mozambique elections, the ruling party took advanatage of the biometrci system used for the diffusion of voter ID cards. In some instances engineers for the Technical Secretariat for Electoral Administration (STAE), the national body in charge of voting logistics, were found tampering with the infrastrtucture necessary to register votes. In some cases, engineers were found manipulating votes on behalf of the ruling party's candidate.

Name: Myanmar
Authentication Method Details: Uses fingerprints, iris scans, palm prints and facial features
ID Medium Details: Smartcard, stores biometric information
Use Cases Details: without a smart card, Burmese citizens would be unable to partake in everyday activities necessary to be a fully functioning citizen.
Interoperatability Details: Necessary to leave the country, but are not recognized or used outside of Myanmar
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Capacity issues in the creation of UID's as there is a larger demand than quantity, and many migrants workers are unable to access UID's due to a lack of capacity leaving them unable to work. Considering ID's are necessary to leave the country under the current administration, a lack of capacity impacts a person's ability to work. Also, the e-ID system is poised to exclude a substantial portion of the popualtion due to the active conflcits in the region that hinder military access. The E-ID system is built on discriminatory laws that bar the Rohingya ethnic group from becoming citizens.
Known Controversies Details: Workers are being pushed to enroll in the e-ID system or risk loosing access to eployment, social security, benefits and freedom of movement. This also, ties into surveillance as with thi in formation, authorities are able to have access to an individuals personal history including, political affiliations and pas arrests.
Funding Source Details: Austrian government and Thales signed an agreement for implementing Biometric E-Id infrastructure as well as funding
Managing Authority: Ministry of Labour, Immigration and Population (MOLIP)
Overview: According to Bloomberg, Myanamrs military government plans to establish a digital currency. Director-general of Central Bank of Myanmar’s currency management department, said the group is “still learning about digital currencies and considering both pros and cons.” (2/2022)

Name: Namibia
Authentication Method Details: Uses Biometrci data as well as a smart card
ID Medium Details: Smart card will contain both biometric and demographic information, there will also be mobile-enambled verification for the delivering of services from the digital ID
Use Cases Details: banking, healthcare, education, elections, and government services.
Interoperatability Details: Namibia has announced that their digital Id's will be compatible to that f Botswana'as as they will have the same QR codes and machinereadable zones as the Botswana ID's, to facilitate cross border movement.
Managing Authority: Ministry of Home Affairs, Immigration, Safety and Security (MHAISS)

Name: Nepal
Authentication Method Details: Biometric adn Demographic Data
ID Medium Details: Uses a biometric smart ID card as well as what is known as the "nagarik" app. This allows the public to access various government services in a single place.
Use Cases Details: government and financial services, digital paltforms, health, migration
Funding Source Details: Nepalese demaprtment of National ID and civil registration, World bank, Asian development Bank (ADB)
Managing Authority: Department of National ID and Civil Registration

Name: Netherlands
Authentication Method Details: Uses mobile phone numbers and two step verification. Also uses traditional username/password login credentials
ID Medium Details: App and Portal
Use Cases Details: government, healthcare and public services, education, taxes
Interoperatability Details: dutch citizens are able to log into the platform from anywhere in the world
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: The main "at risk" population when it comes to inclusivity of the system is the elder population. However, DigiD has offered free courses to facilitate the digital transition of the futh elderly population. There is also the risk of marginalizing refugee populations in the country due to language barriers in education courses. However, more research is needed on the efficiency of inclusivity courses.
Known Controversies Details: Most recent controversy took place in January 2025 when a network failure brought down the service caused by cyberhackers.
Managing Authority: The Minister of the Interior and Kingdom Relations (BZK)

Name: New Zealand
Authentication Method Details: Biometric data through facial recognition technology, Username and passwords and an optional two factor authentication via SMS
ID Medium Details: Portal and App
Use Cases Details: government services education, banking, housing, health, employment, legal and compliance
Interoperatability Details: RealMe ID would not be recognized outside of New Zealand but citizens can access the platform outside of the country

Name: Niger
Authentication Method Details: Biometric data for a biometric passport system and in the second phase of the development, a smartcard digital ID
ID Medium Details: Undecided
Use Cases Details: accessing public/private sectors, cross border service access, regional integration
Interoperatability Details: Digital ID will be part of the West Africa Unique Identification for Regional Integration and Inclusion (WURI), a project built to help people move smoothly regionally as well as facilitate cross border trade.
Managing Authority: Ministry of Interior, Public Security, and Territorial Administration

Name: Nigeria
Authentication Method Details: The National Identification Number system connectivs individuals biometric data for identity verification purposes.
ID Medium Details: Recently, Nigeria has unveiled a secure paltform for the verification and authenticaition of the NIN through an app. This initiaitve has been carried out in order to offer Nigerians a more pleasant digital ID management experience.
Use Cases Details: Financial Services, access to government programs, immigration capabilities
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Regional disparities in the registration for the digital ID in Nigeria. Wealthier and more urban regions like Lagos State record the highest levels of enrollment while states like taraba and Bayelsa lag behind. Also, in many rural regions the absence of a reliable network reflects the low numbers of registration for the digital national ID. The lack of public awareness and education revolving around NIN also continues to be an ongoing challenge for inclusivity.
Funding Source Details: World Bank, French Agency for Development, European Investment Bank

Name: Oman
Authentication Method Details: facial recognition and QR code scanning
ID Medium Details: App and SmartCard
Use Cases Details: government transactions, banking, healthcare, travel
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Oman has been ranked among the top 10 performers globally and regioanlly first in the Digital Accessibility Rights Evaluation. Since 2008, the Omani government has recongized the importance of inclusivity and has made digital services accesisble allowing for the simple registration of "person with disabilities" Also, the government has been successful in imposing multiple legislations, laws and policies revolving around accessibility and supported by both the public and private sector.

Name: Panama
Use Cases Details: facilitating government procedures and improving access to public services

Name: Paraguay
Authentication Method Details: Biometric and OTP
ID Medium Details: App and Portal
Use Cases Details: Drivers Licenses, accessing all government ID couments in one place
Interoperatability Details: Back in 2024, the Inter-American Development Bank and the Inter-American Network on Digital Government  have launched an initiaive that enables citizens of Argentina, Brazil, paraguay and Uruguay to use their national digital ID's for government services across these countries. However, this initiaitve is still in development, Parguayan digital ID's are still not compeltley accepted outside of the country.
Known Controversies Details: Paraguay issuing digital IDS and mDls without adequate regulation, NGO's argue
Technology Providers: Thales, Ministerio de Tecnologías de la Información y Comunicación
Managing Authority: Ministerio de Tecnologias de la Información y Comunicación

Name: Peru
Authentication Method Details: Biometric
ID Medium Details: SmartCard and Portal
Use Cases Details: access to public services, government services, healthcare, drivers license, access to financial entities
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Citizens with disabilities face the possibility of being excluded from voting if a judeg declares a person as lacking mental capacity. Wehn this happens, this characteristic of the indvidual is reflected in the digital ID. Consequently, the person is locked out of their civil rights to vote leading them to have to make the choice between continuing to vote, or receive benefits from the state for their condition.
Known Controversies Details: Workers at the National Registry of Identification and Civil Status suspended services to citizens after demanding the government extend employment of the current head of the institution. This caused services to slow down illustrating the infrastructure issue when it comes to ID roll. Also, citizens have also been experiencing difficulties services due to costant system crashes.
Funding Source Details: Inter-American Development Bank and Peruvian Government
Managing Authority: Registro Nacional de Identificación y Estado Civil (RENIEC)

Name: Puerto Rico
Authentication Method Details: To access the CESCO digital app the citizen must inpiut their social security number (last 4 digits) and demogrpahic information like their birthday. For the actual digital ID (mDL) the virtual card utilizes encrypted communication and biometric authentication to access it.
ID Medium Details: App called CESCO
Use Cases Details: drivers license, housing vouchers, banking, access to government services
Interoperatability Details: The digital ID can be used outside of puerto rico in the United States but to a limited extent. Citizens who wish to travel outside of the country to the US need to make sure TSA accepts their IDs in their select airport locations.
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Currently, the Apple Wallet that contains the digital drivers license for Puerto Rican's can only be accessed if a user has an Iphone XS or later with iOS 18.1 or Apple Watch Series 6 or later. This can pose a problem to those who wish to obtain a diogital copy of the drivers license. However, inclusion risk is moderate because having a digital ID is not a national obligation for those who dont want it.
Technology Providers: Innovatio, Puerto Rico Innovation and technology Service (PRITS), Department of Transporation and Public Works (DTOP)

Name: Senegal
Authentication Method Details: Biometric (fingerprints, facial); PIN, 17 digit card
Use Cases Details: Elections, border control, health insurance (UHC), financial KYC, general public service access
Interoperatability Details: Regional ECOWAS travel; planned national services integration; health-insurance-linked pilot
Data Collected: Full name, DOB, address, biometric (all 10 fingerprints), photo; electoral number
Inclusion & Accessibility Risk Details: Internet penetration 60%; rural/poor populations may face access challenges
Known Controversies Details: Biometric database used for EU deportation operations (2021)
Technology Providers: Iris Corporation (smart cards) ; Innovatrics ABIS for deduplication
Third-Party Access: Government services (tax, police, elections); health systems; financial services (per KYC/AML)
Overview: Senegal operates a fully launched biometric identity system anchored in the CEDEAO biometric ID card, legally instituted in 2016, and a broader national digital ID program initiated in 2022 under its Digital Strategy 2025 . The system collects extensive biometric data—up to ten fingerprints and facial images—embedded on smart cards and managed by Senegal Numérique, ANSD, and the Ministry of Economy & Digital. Integration efforts are ongoing, notably with universal health insurance and financial KYC. While the system supports regional interoperability within ECOWAS, access gaps remain due to internet penetration challenges. Privacy protections exist under Senegal’s data protection authority, though concerns persist around centralized databases and deportation usage. Technology partners include Iris Corp and Innovatrics.
Key Developments:
2016 – Law 2016‑09 and decree establish CEDEAO biometric ID card; Senegal becomes first ECOWAS member to launch
2020–21 – Iris Corp renews contract; Innovatrics ABIS deployed to cleanse and deduplicate >5M records
2021 – System reportedly used in EU deportation processes
2022 – National digital ID program launched with UNDP support as part of Senegal Digital Strategy 2025
2023–27 – Pilot to integrate digital ID with Universal Health Coverage; enrolment of ~18M citizens ongoing
2024 – Digital infrastructure roadmap emphasized, aiming at data protection framework finalization, interoperability, and cybersecurity
Privacy Score: some concerns over central database usage

Name: South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands
United States of America
Authentication Method Details: Information from a mobile driver's license (mDL) is verified using public key cryptography, a system that uses a pair of digital keys. The verifier engages the mDL with an mDL reader, verifies the license using its public key, and retrieves the necessary data. This data can be obtained directly from the holder’s smartphone or from the issuing authority via a server.
Interoperatability Details: Can be used as ID verification at APPROVED TSA airports for domestic travel
Managing Authority: American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators (AAMVA)
